Introduction...
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Praise be to Allah, and peace and blessings be upon the Messenger of Allah, his family, his companions, and those who follow him.
To proceed: Today, I present to the noble readers intriguing research and useful discussions, if Allah the Exalted wills. It offers them a new color of combined Hadith and Fiqh scientific verification regarding a very important issue that often arises for some, the need for it, and knowing the correct opinion regarding it. That is: "The fasting person breaking his fast in Ramadan before his travel after dawn."
It is indeed strange that some people today proceed to deny the Hadith reported regarding this, which defines for the Muslim the stance he must take regarding it, despite the authenticity of its chain of narration (Isnad), the probity of its narrators, its conformity with the apparent meaning of the Qur'an, the testimony of the Salaf's traditions (Athar) for it, and its agreement with a principle from the principles of the glorious Sharia: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE

...hardship} [Al-Baqarah: 185], and a group of Imams of Fiqh and Hadith acted upon it. [Their denial] is nothing but partisanship for their jurisprudential branch, contrary to what was authentically reported from their Imam as a principle among his principles: "If the Hadith is authentic, then it is my madhhab (school of thought)."
I had published these researches in the flourishing magazine "Al-Tamaddun Al-Islami" (Issues 25-36, year 1379) in three consecutive articles. It then appeared to me to separate them from the magazine and publish them in an independent treatise as they appeared in the magazine, hoping that the benefit from them would be more widespread and our reward, if Allah the Exalted wills, would be greater.
I ask Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, to make it purely for His Noble Face and to bring about general benefit through it.
Damascus, evening of the Day of Arafah, year 1379 AH.
Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani.

edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
Entrance...
The Professor Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani previously commented with a word on a fatwa in this magazine regarding this subject, clarifying that it is from the Sunnah for the fasting person to break his fast in his house before leaving it. We received a word from Professor Sheikh Abdullah bin Muhammad al-Harari - through Professor Sheikh Hamdi al-Juwayjani - in which he mentioned that some readers presented that word [of Al-Albani] to him, and he saw it as relying on a weak Hadith. We showed Professor Al-Albani the word of Professor Al-Harari, so he supported what he held previously with a new word. We publish the two words in what follows:

1 - Professor Al-Harari said:
"In the Jami' of Al-Tirmidhi: Chapter regarding one who eats then leaves for travel. Qutaybah narrated to us, Abdullah bin Ja'far narrated to us, from Zaid bin Aslam, from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir, from Muhammad bin Ka'b who said: I came to Anas bin Malik in Ramadan while he intended to travel; his mount had been prepared and he had worn the clothes of travel. He called for food and ate. I said: 'Is it Sunnah?' He said: 'It is Sunnah.' Then...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...he rode.
Muhammad bin Ismail narrated to us, Sa'id bin Abi Maryam narrated to us, Muhammad bin Ja'far narrated to us, Zaid bin Aslam narrated to me, Muhammad bin al-Munkadir narrated to me, from Muhammad bin Ka'b who said: I came to Anas bin Malik in Ramadan, and he mentioned something similar.
Abu Isa [Al-Tirmidhi] said: This is a Hasan (Good) Hadith. Muhammad bin Ja'far is Ibn Abi Kathir, a Madinan, trustworthy (Thiqah), and he is the brother of Ismail bin Ja'far. Abdullah bin Ja'far is Ibn Abi Najih, the father of Ali bin al-Madini, and Yahya bin Ma'in used to weaken him. Some people of knowledge have adopted this Hadith and said: The traveler may break his fast in his house before he leaves, and he may not shorten the prayer until he exits the wall of the city or the village. This is the saying of Ishaq.
This grading of 'Hasan' by Al-Tirmidhi is rejected, for two Hafizs (Memorizers of Hadith) have weakened this Hadith; one from the predecessors and the other from the successors:

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
The first: The critic Hafiz Abu Hatim al-Razi. His son, Hafiz Abdur-Rahman, said in 'Al-Ilal' (p. 240) the following text: 'I asked my father about a Hadith narrated by Abdul-Aziz bin Muhammad al-Darawardi from Zaid bin Aslam from Muhammad bin Ka'b that he came to Anas bin Malik in Ramadan while he intended to travel, and he found that his mount had been prepared and he had worn the clothes of travel. He called for food and ate. We said: Is it Sunnah? He said: It is not Sunnah. And Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman bin Mujbar narrated it from Ibn al-Munkadir from Muhammad bin Ka'b that he came to Anas bin Malik... and he mentioned the Hadith. He said: I said: Is it Sunnah? He said: It is Sunnah. My father said: The Hadith of Al-Darawardi is more correct.' End quote.
This is, as is apparent, explicit that the narration of Al-Tirmidhi is outweighed (Marjuh) and that the preponderant narration is the narration of negation.
The second: He is Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi, Zain al-Din Abdur-Rahim, the Sheikh of...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...Hafiz Ibn Hajar. He said in his commentary on Al-Tirmidhi: 'There is a manuscript copy in the Mahmudiya Library in Medina, number 168': This Hadith of Anas was uniquely narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, and he graded it Hasan due to the follow-up (Mutaba'ah) of Muhammad bin Ja'far for Abdullah bin Ja'far. Otherwise, Abdullah is weak, as the author reported his weakening from Ibn Ma'in, for he said regarding him: He is nothing. Abu Hatim al-Razi said regarding him: Very Munkar (denounced) in Hadith. Al-Nasa'i said regarding him: Matruk (abandoned) in Hadith. Al-Fallas said: Weak in Hadith. Al-Daraqutni said regarding him: Has many Munkar narrations. Abu Hatim said: He used to have delusions in reports, bringing them inverted, and he makes mistakes in traditions (Athar) so that they seem inverted. Ibn Adi said: Most of his Hadiths are not followed up by anyone, but despite his weakness, he is among those whose Hadith is written down. The author of Al-Mizan said: He is agreed upon to be weak. End quote.
He said: And Al-Tirmidhi only graded the Hadith Hasan because Abdullah bin Ja'far was not alone in narrating it; rather, Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir followed him up in it...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...Al-Madani, and he is trustworthy (Thiqah) as Al-Tirmidhi said.
If this is established, there is a matter that must be noted: The point of evidence in the Hadith is Anas saying in it that 'it is Sunnah'. The ruling of a Companion on a 'matter' that it is Sunnah takes the ruling of a Marfu' (traceable to the Prophet) Hadith, as is established in the sciences of Hadith and Usul. This phrase was only narrated with certainty (Jazm) by Abdullah bin Ja'far, and he is agreed upon to be weak as mentioned previously.
As for the path of Muhammad bin Ja'far, Al-Tirmidhi did not cite its wording; rather, he said, 'and he mentioned something similar'. This does not imply that it is identical in wording, as is established in the sciences of Hadith.
Then we searched for the wording of the narration of Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir, and we found that he did not state this phrase with certainty as Abdullah bin Ja'far did. Ismail bin Ishaq Al-Qadi narrated it likewise in the book 'Al-Siyam'. He said: Isa bin Mina narrated to us, he said: Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir narrated to us, from Zaid bin Aslam, from Ibn al-Munkadir, from Muhammad bin Ka'b...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...he said: I came to Anas bin Malik in Ramadan while he intended to travel, so he ate. I said: 'Sunnah?' I do not think but that he said: 'Yes.'
This is the wording of Muhammad bin Ja'far's narration, and some of its narrators doubted regarding this phrase which is the basis of the argument. However, Al-Daraqutni narrated it in his Sunan from Abu Bakr al-Naysaburi from Ismail bin Ishaq bin Sahl from Ibn Abi Maryam from Muhammad bin Ja'far, and he mentioned it and did not doubt regarding this phrase; rather he said: I said: 'Sunnah?' He said: 'Yes.'
Ibn al-Arabi said: The Hadith of Anas is authentic (Sahih), but no one adopted it except Ahmad bin Hanbal.
I say: There is disagreement regarding it upon Ali bin Sa'id bin Abi Maryam. Ismail bin Ishaq reported from him what preceded, while Yahya bin Ayyub al-Allaf contradicted him and made the story about breaking the fast on the Day of Doubt, not the intention to travel. Al-Tabarani narrated it likewise in 'Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat'. He said: Yahya bin Ayyub al-Allaf narrated to us, he said: Sa'id bin Abi Maryam narrated to us, narrated to us...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir from Zaid bin Aslam from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir from Muhammad bin Ka'b who said: I entered upon Anas bin Malik at Asr time on a day they were doubting [whether it was Ramadan or not], and I wanted to greet him. He called for food and ate. I said: 'Is what you have done Sunnah?' He said: 'Yes.'
Khalid bin Nazar followed up Sa'id bin Abi Maryam on his narration in this manner. Al-Tabarani also narrated it in 'Al-Awsat', saying: Al-Miqdam, who is Ibn Dawud, narrated to us, Khalid bin Nazar narrated to us, Muhammad bin Ja'far narrated to us. So if the Hadith is disturbed (Mudtarib), it is not authentic.
Then we searched to see if we could find anyone who followed up Abdullah bin Ja'far and Muhammad bin Ja'far in narrating this Hadith from Zaid bin Aslam to strengthen one of the two narrations. We found Abdul-Aziz bin Muhammad al-Darawardi, who is one of the narrators of the Sahih, had narrated it from Zaid bin Aslam contrary to the narration of Abdullah bin Ja'far. Ismail Al-Qadi also narrated it likewise. He said: Ali bin al-Madini and Ibrahim bin...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...Hamzah narrated to us from Al-Darawardi from Zaid bin Aslam with his chain of narration, and he said in it: So I said to him: 'Sunnah?' He said: 'No', then he rode.
This path is stronger than the path of Abdullah bin Ja'far. So we found the two paths to be authentic: one contains doubt regarding the phrase, and the other contradicts it. In Al-Tabarani, the Hadith is carried upon a meaning other than breaking fast for travel. Thus, the weakness of the narration affirming it as Sunnah becomes clear. And Allah knows best.
Scholars have differed on this issue upon several opinions:
The first: Which is the opinion of the majority of scholars, that whoever starts the day fasting and then travels, he is not permitted to break his fast that day at all, neither before commencing travel nor after it. This is the opinion of Ibrahim al-Nakha'i, Al-Zuhri, Yahya bin Sa'id al-Ansari, Al-Awza'i, Abu Hanifa and his companions, Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and Abu Thawr.
The second: That he may break his fast if he leaves and emerges beyond the houses. This is the opinion of Ahmad bin Hanbal, and it was narrated from Abdullah bin Umar and Al-Sha'bi.

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
Some of them argued for the permissibility of breaking the fast with the authentic Hadith regarding his (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) leaving in Ramadan for Mecca, and that he fasted until he reached Al-Kadid, then he broke his fast. In a narration: 'until he reached Kura' al-Ghamim'. So whoever used this as evidence imagined that Al-Kadid and Al-Kura' are near Medina and that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) started the day in Medina fasting and then reached them in the remainder of his day and broke his fast. Thus, using this Hadith as evidence for that is invalid.
The third: That he may break his fast if he places his foot in the saddle. This was said by Dawud, and Ibn Abd al-Barr related it from Ishaq. This is contrary to what Al-Tirmidhi related from him [Ishaq], that he may break his fast in his house before he leaves, unless it is interpreted that he placed his foot in the saddle while he was in his house then ate before leaving. But the Hadith of Anas contradicts it in that he called for his food and ate then rode. And Allah knows best.
The fourth: That he may break his fast in his house on the day he intends to leave. This is the opinion of Anas and Al-Hasan al-Basri as narrated from him, and the author [Al-Tirmidhi] related it from...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...Ibn Rahwaih as preceded.
Ibn Abd al-Barr said: 'They agreed regarding the one who intends to travel in Ramadan that it is not permissible for him to intend to break the fast the night before, because the traveler does not become a traveler by intention; he only becomes a traveler by setting out on his journey.' End of Al-Iraqi's words.
Al-Bukhari narrated from Ibn Abbas: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) left Medina in Ramadan with ten thousand Muslims; he fasted and they fasted until he reached Al-Kadid, then he broke the fast and they broke the fast.
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: If one intends to fast while resident then travels during the day, is he permitted to break his fast during that day? The majority forbade it. Ahmad and Ishaq said it is permissible, and Al-Muzani chose it, using this Hadith as evidence. It was said to him: He said that thinking that he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) broke the fast on the day he left Medina. But it is not so, for between Medina and Al-Kadid are several days.
Likewise, there is no proof for the opponent in the Hadith of Abu Basrah al-Ghifari which Ahmad and Abu Dawood narrated via Ubayd bin Jubayr who said: I rode...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...with Abu Basrah al-Ghifari in a ship from Fustat in Ramadan. He pushed off, then brought his morning meal (Ghada') near, then said: 'Come near.' I said: 'Do you not see the houses?' He said: 'Do you desire to turn away from the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)?' So he ate.
[There is no proof in this] for two reasons:
First: According to the reliable view, Abu Dawood's silence on what he narrates in his Sunan is not sufficient for the authenticity of the Hadith. Rather, it must be examined, and that is the task of the Hafiz (Hadith master), as established in the sciences of Hadith regarding the condition of memorization (Hifz) for distinguishing the authentic from the sickly Hadith, as stated by Al-Hakim in 'Ma'rifat Ulum al-Hadith'. As for the claim of this opponent that he possesses such qualification himself, it is but an empty claim.
Second: Even if it were authentic, there is no proof in it, because it does not state that he left after dawn then rode then ate. It is possible that he left his house before dawn and boarded the ship, so eating became permissible for him, as is the position of the majority: that whoever leaves before dawn is permitted to eat during that very day, unlike whoever leaves after dawn, for he may not break his fast in...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...that day, except for what follows it.
What supports our interpretation of this Hadith is the narrator's saying: 'then he brought his Ghada' (morning meal) near'. Al-Ghada' in the language is what is eaten at the beginning of the day, contrary to what is customary today in the colloquial language where Al-Ghada' (lunch) is applied to what is eaten in the middle of the day just before noon or after it, for this is a newly invented usage. In 'Al-Qamus': 'Al-Ghada' is the food of the Ghadwah (early morning), and 'taghadda' means he ate at the beginning of the day.' And in it: 'Al-Ghadwah: The early morning or what is between the Fajr prayer and sunrise.' And Allah knows best."

edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
2 - Muhammad Nasir al-Din says, seeking help from Allah alone, the Lord of the worlds:
The Sheikh's words are confined to four matters:
First: Weakening the Hadith of Anas.
Second: The Fiqh (jurisprudence) of the Hadith and who held that opinion.
Third: Weakening the Hadith of Abu Basrah al-Ghifari.
Fourth: Its lack of indication, according to him, of what the Hadith of Anas indicated.
I will discuss these matters in what follows, one after another in the mentioned order, asking the Master, Glory be to Him and Exalted is He, to inspire me with correctness in all of that and to grant success to the sincere ones to accept it and act upon the Fiqh contained therein. Indeed, He is Hearing and Responsive.

1 - Confirmation of the Authenticity of Anas's Hadith.
As for the Hadith of Anas, I contemplated the Sheikh's words regarding it, and I found in them nothing but what increased my insight into its authenticity and certainty regarding the weakness of his speech and the flimsiness of what he clung to in weakening it. For he did not bring against what it indicates anything that is suitable...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...to be considered a doubt (Shubhah) regarding its authenticity, let alone being a proof for its weakness, if that were presented to the rules of the science of Hadith and its principles and the testimonies of the scholars to its establishment. Here is the detail:
The Sheikh had the audacity - contrary to what we knew of him in some of his treatises - to assert decisively the error of Al-Tirmidhi in his grading of the Hadith as Hasan, and he did not care at all about Imam Ibn al-Arabi's grading of it as authentic (Sahih) and others whom we will mention. He clung in doing so to matters that can be summarized in four:
First: Abu Hatim's preference for the narration of Al-Darawardi with the wording: "It is not Sunnah" over the other narration: "He said: Yes, Sunnah." We will express it as "The Narration of Affirmation".
Second: Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi's weakening of the other narration.
Third: The lack of certainty (Jazm) of some narrators regarding it.
Fourth: The disagreement regarding its text (Matn) upon Sa'id bin Abi Maryam; some mentioned from him: that the breaking of the fast was due to travel, and some that it...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...was due to the Day of Doubt.

The Answer to the First Matter:
1- If that is clear, we say in answering the first matter:
First: Understanding Abu Hatim's saying: "The Hadith of Al-Darawardi is more correct than the Hadith of Ibn Mujbar" to mean that the narration of Al-Tirmidhi is outweighed and weak, and that the preponderant one is the narration of negation, indicates - unfortunately - extreme ignorance of the methods of the Muhaddithin in weighing preferences (Tarjih) and a misunderstanding of their intents behind that. For Abu Hatim's preference is limited between two narrations, neither of which is Al-Tirmidhi's narration. Furthermore, it is a correct preference because Al-Darawardi is trustworthy (Thiqah) despite slight weakness in his memory as will come, unlike his opponent: Ibn Mujbar, for he is agreed to be weak. Abu Hatim himself said about him: "Not strong," and his companion Abu Zur'ah said: "Wahi al-Hadith" (Flimsy in Hadith).
foot_note: 1. "Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil" by Ibn Abi Hatim "3/2/320".

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
But what scholar, nay what sane person possessing a little understanding of Arabic style, understands from this a preference of this narration of Al-Darawardi over the narration of Al-Tirmidhi, when the latter was not mentioned in Abu Hatim's words, neither explicitly nor implicitly? Indeed, perhaps he did not come across it at all. Moreover, it [Al-Tirmidhi's narration] is stronger and more preponderant than Al-Darawardi's narration, as I will explain in the following point.
Thus falls the Sheikh's saying following Abu Hatim's words: "It is explicit that the narration of Al-Tirmidhi is outweighed and that the preponderant narration is the narration of negation."
Second: Al-Darawardi's saying in his narration "It is not Sunnah" is Munkar (denounced) or at least Shadh (anomalous) for two reasons:
A - His contradiction of one who is more trustworthy than him, namely Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir, who is trustworthy (Thiqah) as Al-Tirmidhi said, and the Sheikh himself quoted it from him. There is no dispute regarding him among the critical Imams; rather, the Two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim] and all the authors of the Sunan relied on him as proof. So his narration is the preponderant one upon...

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
...conflict over the narration of Al-Darawardi, because the latter is disputed. Abu Zur'ah and others described him as having "bad memory", so naturally Al-Bukhari did not use him as proof, whereas they all used his opponent [Muhammad bin Ja'far] as proof.
Thus it is established that his narration is more deserving of preference than Al-Darawardi's narration, and no fair person who has smelled the scent of Hadith terminology doubts this.
B - That Al-Darawardi's narration has no follower (Mutaabi') and no witness (Shahid), contrary to the narration of Muhammad bin Ja'far, for it has a follower and a witness:
As for the follower (Mutaabi'), it is Abdullah bin Ja'far in Al-Tirmidhi. Even if he is weak, his Hadith is written down as Ibn Adi said, so he is acceptable in follow-ups and witnesses.
As for the witness (Shahid), it is the Hadith of Ibn al-Mujbar which the Sheikh quoted from Ibn Abi Hatim. His weakness does not harm because it is in [the context of] witnesses, as is not hidden, and I do not think the Sheikh disagrees with that because he mentioned something similar in his treatise "Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith" (p. 5).

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
Thus, by this verification, the Sheikh's attachment to Abu Hatim's words falls, and it becomes clear that the correct version is the Narration of Affirmation, and that Al-Darawardi's narration of negation is an error that cannot be relied upon.

The Answer to the Second Matter:
2 - As for the second matter, which is Al-Iraqi's weakening of the Narration of Affirmation, the answer is from two aspects:
First: Opposing it with the authentication of those who authenticated the Hadith, and they are a group. Their saying is weightier upon conflict than the saying of one who opposed them, who is an individual. Among those who authenticated it: Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn al-Arabi, Al-Diya al-Maqdisi - as will come - Ibn al-Qayyim in "Zad al-Ma'ad", and Abu al-Mahasin al-Maqdisi in "Mukhtasar Ahadith al-Ahkam" (fol. 61/1). To them can be added Imam Ahmad and Ishaq bin Rahwaih, for they adopted the Hadith and acted upon it by Al-Iraqi's own admission, and that is proof - if Allah the Exalted wills - that the Hadith is established according to them, which is the desired point.

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn
edition: The only legitimate edition 1421 AH - 2001 CE
text:
Second: That the rules of the science of Hadith indicate the error of the mentioned weakening. I hope that neither the Professor Sheikh nor any of those partisan to him or others will exploit this to hasten to denounce us because of this declaration, for the truth is above persons, and scientific verification knows no hypocrisy.
Moreover, the Sheikh has preceded me to such fault-finding; he decided on Al-Tirmidhi's error as you saw. So likewise, I decide on the error of Al-Iraqi and the Sheikh together, with a fundamental difference between me and him. He faults Al-Tirmidhi in imitation of Al-Iraqi, and this is preferring without a preferrer (Tarjih bila Murajjih) as is not hidden. If someone were to reverse the matter on him and imitate Al-Tirmidhi and fault Al-Iraqi, he would find no way to fault him except mere claim or following desire. As for us, we only find fault by following the scientific rules that scholars established as a scale to know error from correctness. What a difference between this and that.

book_title: Correction of the Hadith about the Fasting Person Breaking Fast Before Travel After Dawn

4 - The Indication of the Hadith for what Anas's Hadith indicated.
As for the Sheikh's saying: "If the Hadith were authentic, there is no proof in it, because it does not state that he left after the morning (Subh) then rode then ate. It is possible that he left his house before dawn." I say: The mentioned possibility is invalid for several reasons:
First: It is contrary to what immediately comes to mind from the hadith.

Second: It is contrary to what the scholars who extracted it understood from it. Here is Abu Dawood titling it saying: "Chapter: When does the traveler break fast if he leaves?" He indicates by that that Abu Basrah left fasting then broke the fast. Also, Al-Majd Ibn Taymiyyah titled it saying: "Whoever travels during the day, does he break fast in it? And when does he break fast?" Similar to it and more explicit is the saying of Al-Bayhaqi coming shortly, if Allah the Exalted wills.
Third: If Abu Basrah had left before dawn - as the Sheikh claimed - it would mean that he traveled before fasting became obligatory upon him due to the absence of its condition, which is residency (Iqamah). It is known that for such a person, eating after dawn is permissible by the text of the Quran and the agreement of Muslims; indeed, some obligated it upon him. Since the matter is so, is it conceivable that Ubayd bin Jabr would object to him saying: "Do you not see the houses?" There is no doubt that this statement from him is proof that Abu Basrah left fasting and that he ate after dawn and broke the fast.
